THE PUBLIC DEBATE.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

record to sustain, for they had the honor last
year of defeating the team of 1900. The Juniors
were desirous of making a reputation. According to a remark made by Dr. Lee before
the debate, the Senior team beat the Juniors
in experience and speaking ability, but not in
power of close thought; and it was the latter
complimentary characterization that had given
1902 some hope of conquering the heroes of
last year's conflict. The speeches were mostly
composite, having been "executed" by all
members of the teams. As the question stood,
the affirmative had a double burden to bear,—
not only the burden of the proof, but also the
burden of four distinct points; and, though it
was thought by some that their arguments
were superior to those advanced by the negative, but they had too much to prove, otherwise the question was as strong for one side as
the other. The decision in justice went to the
Seniors, who defended the negative of the
question that "The United States should construct,own,operate and control an inter-oceanic
canal by way of the Nicaraguan route."
J. G. Campbell led for the affirmative. He
arose, somewhat embarassed by the large
crowd. He was very effective, and showed
the evidences of a natural speaker well trained.
He was possibly overtrained, as a conscious
effort for effect was noticeable, which tended
to detract attention from the substance of his
speech to the delivery. His speech was filled
with arguments which he delivered convincingly.
A. R. Bird, who was the first speaker for
the negative, pleased the audience. He has a
soft, well-modulated voice, calculated to affect
the many maidens in the hall in a tender manner. He brought up in short, sharp sentences
all the points of the negative; but, owing to the
fact that he lost the thread of his speech once
or twice, the continuity of his argument was
broken. He gesticulated well, and, on the
whole, was interesting, though not the orator
that Campbell is.
Harvey B. Stone followed Bird, and carried
off the prize for the most effective speaker of
the evening. Stone spoke almost altogether
extemporaneously, but in his flow of hard,

hitting language this was hardly noticed. He
was perfectly at ease, and "got on" with the
audience in his very first words. His voice
was not good, but his style made up for that
failing. He thought quickly, and spoke epigrammaticaliy and naturally, hammering away
with all his might at the arguments of the negative. Stone is a convincing speaker.
J. A. Riggins came second for the negative
with a prepared speech in which he dwelt
almost exclusively on the word "control" of
the question. He was well trained, had a
good presence, and brought forward arguments
which must have convinced the judges.
Charles Markell, Jr., who summed up for
the affirmative, was apparently nervous. Having the most difficult position on his side to
defend, and one that is not enviable, he did
well. His flow of language was good,—in
fact, too good; for he had the tendency to talk
too much around the point. He gave two or
three excellent sentences on the fact that a
neutral canal was not a possibility, but he
should have continued more on this, point.
Considering all the difficulties Markell had to
overcome, he was good, but could have been
better.
J. G. Machen was the last man of the evening, and was probably the strongest. The
calm, cold logic which he, in his sincere, natural manner, poured forth .was convincing.
He was at home on the stage, his voice wellsustained, and his manner impressive. He
spoke so earnestly that one was almost tempted
to accept what he said, as the best arguments.
The result of the debate shows that there is
plenty of good material at Hopkins for a collegiate team to compete with some of the best
in this country. There is some possibility of
engaging certain colleges in debating contests;
let us stick by Dr. Lee in his stand that "it is
better to be licked by a crack team than to
defeat a small college," and we will have some
chance of getting in good, appropriate company.
In all the speakers the effect of Dr. Lee's
training was evident, so that he has every
reason to feel satisfied with the night's work.
The Senior alternates were: J. E. Tyler, J.

Saturday will afford an opportunity
NEXT
for witnessing the "initial performance"
of our Lacrosse Team, for the season of 1901.
We will then be enabled to form some idea of
our strength and our chance for a procession
of victories. Undoubtedly the team will suffer
on account of the loss of such men as Maddren
and McInnes, and the gaps caused by their
departure will be difficult to fill; but, judging
from the earliest work of the team during the
past two months, it is easy to perceive that
good material is not lacking, and that the
present lot of new candidates promises to turn
out some excellent men.
It is safe to say that not a single Hopkins
student doubts for a moment the ability of our
Lacrosse Team to maintain the standard set by
our Lacrosse teams of the past three years.
In order to prove this, let those who do not
play, remember that they can afford assistance
and encouragement to the team by coming to
the games and "rooting."
WWW

HE recent inter-class debate and the standard of excellence attained by the speakers
of both sides, again re-opens the old question,
"Why doesn't Hopkins participate in interuniversity debates ?" Ranking as she does in
point of curriculum and scholastic pre-eminence, our University should certainly be capable of holding her own with any of the "Big
Four" in a debating contest.
Lack of numbers handicaps us to a greater
or less extent upon the athletic field, but in a
case of brain pitted against brain, and muscle,
for the time being, left out of the question, the
odds would not be overwhelmingly against
us. Inter-University debates would bring us
into closer relation with the other great unisities of America, and would enable us to make
comparisons. Finally, as a business proposition, it would possess inestimable advantages
in placing Hopkins more prominently before
the public eye. This would enable the public
not only of Baltimore, but of more remote
places, to pass upon the merits of Hopkins, and
might go far towards enabling us to raise the
necessary funds for our new home.

T

misapprehension has arisen regarding
SOME
an article relating to base ball and last
year's base ball team, which appeared in the
last issue of the NEWS-LETTER. It is certainly
true that lack of interest on the part of the
players themselves was alone responsible for
the discontinuance of the national game at
Hopkins, but while these gentlemen deserve
the censure of the University, the manager of
their team merits no share of the condemnation. His efforts to preserve the morale of the
team and make it a credit to Hopkins were
known to all who were here last year. He
had secured a good schedule and the co-operation of the players was all that was necessary.
Unfortunately this support was not forthcoming, and, despite his efforts, the men would
not work, so consequently the team passed
out of existence.
In justification of Mr. Strouse, we say that
had the other ball-players of last year's nine
been as enthusiastic and faithful as he, base
ball at Hopkins would now be a reality instead
of a sorrowful thing of the past.

The "Eysterian Quartette" did its accustomed stunts and exhausted its stock in trade.
The evening closed with "'Rah for the
Black Boys," and a rousing "Hullabaloo."
The proceeds of the concert are to go towards defraying the expenses incurred by the
Athletic Association in fixing up the new
grounds on the York Road. It is likely that
six or seven hundred dollars will be handed
over to the Athletic Association, and it seems
that every Hopkins man should be grateful to
the Musical Clubs. It should also be known
that the Clubs agreed to give this benefit concert at a time when they were assured of a
large audience at their own concert.

Peter Jenness, a student in the Electric Department in '99, has returned to Baltimore
from Paris, where he has been engaged in business.

The last series, of lectures before the students
of Historical and Political Science is to be given

the Union."

The class of 1900 is arranging with Manager
Lawlor of the Johns Hopkins Club for a class
reunion and dinner, to be held at the Club, on

At its last banquet, the class of '92 decided
to erect a building, or other memorial of the
class, at Homewood, in the event of the University moving there. The committee in charge
of the arrangements consists of Messers.Greenbaum, Stevens, Whitehead, John Stewart, and
Dr. Thos. R. Brown, President of the class.

The University of Glasgow has invited the
Johns Hopkins University to send representatives to its ninth Jubilee, which is to be held
on the 12, 13, and 14 of June. It has been decided to send one delegate from the faculty,
and two from the student body, but final arrangements have not yet been completed. There
will be great pageants and processions, as well
as speeches by prominent men: and the entertainment generally is to be on a grand scale.
JP Jib

Poultney Biglow, who delivered two lectures
on Colonization before the students of historical and political science, March 28 and 30, is a
most interesting character, as scholar, war correspondent, and sportsman. He was the representative of the London "Times" on the
field during the Spanish-American War. He
was the first man to pass in a canoe through
the Iron Gates of the Danube ; and he belongs
to the yacht clubs in Russia, England, and the
United States. His writings on government
and colonial administration, give the view of a
contemporary observer of keen insight, and
are most valuable historical works.

Team met in the Donovan Room, and passed a
resolution authorizing the chairman to thank
Mr. Carver and Dr. Lee for their kindness and
attention in training the speakers for the debate.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
INQUIRY COLUMN.
(In this column the NEWS LETTER will answer, to the best of
its ability, the queries forwarded by correspondents.)

To the Editor:
Could you give me an estimate of the number of students enrolled in the various American colleges?
—Inquirer.
The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER has never
won a prize in a guessing contest, but would
advise Inquirer as a safe way of answering his
question to write to all the colleges for registers. He may then compute the number of
students, and if he will hand his computation

number of freckles that mar my beauty. I
have tried any number of remedies for them,

you can help me.
—A Vassar Freshie.
Here is one cure for the trouble you speak
of that has never been known to fail. We do
not know whether it will help you or not, but
it will not hurt you to try. Just before retiring rub about 5 grains concentrated nitric acid
(H N 03)on the spots affected. If it burns
at first, put some more on. All sense of pain
will soon pass away, and the result will surprise you in the morning.

Please tell me how I should eat the sandwiches sold in the lunch-room. It is rather
hard to manage them without attracting considerable attention to the performance.
—Sub-Fresh.
Proceed as follows: Place sandwich on floor,
and set foot firmly on its neck. Be sure to
use plenty of strength, as you are dealing with
a dangerous creature. Now take your spade
and cut deeply into its back, and before it
can squirm loose, extract the ribs and false
teeth. After this it is harmless. Just break
in small pieces with an ax or sledge, and eat it
before it gets warm. Another thing, don't
mind attracting notice. That's what we're
here for.

T Hopkins when my funds are low,
And cheaply I must live and slow,
How fast and furious is the flow
Of bills that come incessantly.

But Hopkins saw another sight,
When aunty up and croaked one night,
For then I'd dough and checks could write;
And creditors came rapidly.
"We're sorry the mistake was made,
We always knew the bills 'd be paid,
And never were the least afraid,"
And thus they spinaged lyingly.
I paid the bills upon the spot,
And from them all receipts I got,
Then proudly turned and viewed the lot
All full of meek apology.
I called them all the names I knew,
Then ope'd the door and pushed them through,
And kicked the last one good and true,
And watched them scatter hurriedly.
I turned around and closed the door,
Then in a heap sank to the floor,
And gave vent to a mighty roar

On the paper before him a figure was drawn
Of circles, and curves, and straight lines,
Rectangles, triangles, points, planes, and so on,
With letters and wonderful signs.
"I've worked here," he said,"for three hours or more,"
And everything now would he well
And as simple and easy as "twice two makes four,"
If these lines were not parallel.
"If they only would meet! How I wish that they
could!"
Then he stopped in amazement and fright—
One parallel line had arisen and bowed,
And the other in tones quite polite,
Was saying, "I'm happy to meet you, in truth,
And it's doubtless quite needless to state
That this pleasure is all unexpected, forsooth,
For men said we never could meet.
But now we are free from such tyrranous laws,"
It was true, as the student could see.
What confusion, what chaos were reigning because
Of the wish he had made recklessly.
He'd noticed two points, well-behaved here-tofore,
Conversing in whispers apart,
They were planning rebellion, of that he was sure;
He listened and heard with faint heart.
"The law that two points on a straight line shall lie,
No longer is binding on us,
I'm not on a straight line with you, so good bye."
0, what a bewildering muss!
Then he saw a point up on a steeple in town,
And a straight line was standing below,
And the wicked point dropped perpendiculars down
In lots of a dozen or so.
"Only one perpendicular, so we are told,
Can be dropped from a point to a line;
Here goes ten or twenty, that law doesn't hold
Any more than the others. How fine!"
Then he saw a triangle, rejoicing because
He possessed two right angles. What fun!
Hitherto, on account of those same irksome laws,
He had never possessed more than one.
A straight line ran up to a circle, and swore
As he stabbed him four times with a knife,
"I could cut you in only two places before,
But this time you forfeit your life."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

record to sustain, for they had the honor last
year of defeating the team of 1900. The Juniors
were desirous of making a reputation. According to a remark made by Dr. Lee before
the debate, the Senior team beat the Juniors
in experience and speaking ability, but not in
power of close thought; and it was the latter
complimentary characterization that had given
1902 some hope of conquering the heroes of
last year's conflict. The speeches were mostly
composite, having been "executed" by all
members of the teams. As the question stood,
the affirmative had a double burden to bear,—
not only the burden of the proof, but also the
burden of four distinct points; and, though it
was thought by some that their arguments
were superior to those advanced by the negative, but they had too much to prove, otherwise the question was as strong for one side as
the other. The decision in justice went to the
Seniors, who defended the negative of the
question that "The United States should construct,own,operate and control an inter-oceanic
canal by way of the Nicaraguan route."
J. G. Campbell led for the affirmative. He
arose, somewhat embarassed by the large
crowd. He was very effective, and showed
the evidences of a natural speaker well trained.
He was possibly overtrained, as a conscious
effort for effect was noticeable, which tended
to detract attention from the substance of his
speech to the delivery. His speech was filled
with arguments which he delivered convincingly.
A. R. Bird, who was the first speaker for
the negative, pleased the audience. He has a
soft, well-modulated voice, calculated to affect
the many maidens in the hall in a tender manner. He brought up in short, sharp sentences
all the points of the negative; but, owing to the
fact that he lost the thread of his speech once
or twice, the continuity of his argument was
broken. He gesticulated well, and, on the
whole, was interesting, though not the orator
that Campbell is.
Harvey B. Stone followed Bird, and carried
off the prize for the most effective speaker of
the evening. Stone spoke almost altogether
extemporaneously, but in his flow of hard,

hitting language this was hardly noticed. He
was perfectly at ease, and "got on" with the
audience in his very first words. His voice
was not good, but his style made up for that
failing. He thought quickly, and spoke epigrammaticaliy and naturally, hammering away
with all his might at the arguments of the negative. Stone is a convincing speaker.
J. A. Riggins came second for the negative
with a prepared speech in which he dwelt
almost exclusively on the word "control" of
the question. He was well trained, had a
good presence, and brought forward arguments
which must have convinced the judges.
Charles Markell, Jr., who summed up for
the affirmative, was apparently nervous. Having the most difficult position on his side to
defend, and one that is not enviable, he did
well. His flow of language was good,—in
fact, too good; for he had the tendency to talk
too much around the point. He gave two or
three excellent sentences on the fact that a
neutral canal was not a possibility, but he
should have continued more on this, point.
Considering all the difficulties Markell had to
overcome, he was good, but could have been
better.
J. G. Machen was the last man of the evening, and was probably the strongest. The
calm, cold logic which he, in his sincere, natural manner, poured forth .was convincing.
He was at home on the stage, his voice wellsustained, and his manner impressive. He
spoke so earnestly that one was almost tempted
to accept what he said, as the best arguments.
The result of the debate shows that there is
plenty of good material at Hopkins for a collegiate team to compete with some of the best
in this country. There is some possibility of
engaging certain colleges in debating contests;
let us stick by Dr. Lee in his stand that "it is
better to be licked by a crack team than to
defeat a small college," and we will have some
chance of getting in good, appropriate company.
In all the speakers the effect of Dr. Lee's
training was evident, so that he has every
reason to feel satisfied with the night's work.

Saturday will afford an opportunity
NEXT
for witnessing the "initial performance"
of our Lacrosse Team, for the season of 1901.
We will then be enabled to form some idea of
our strength and our chance for a procession
of victories. Undoubtedly the team will suffer
on account of the loss of such men as Maddren
and McInnes, and the gaps caused by their
departure will be difficult to fill; but, judging
from the earliest work of the team during the
past two months, it is easy to perceive that
good material is not lacking, and that the
present lot of new candidates promises to turn
out some excellent men.
It is safe to say that not a single Hopkins
student doubts for a moment the ability of our
Lacrosse Team to maintain the standard set by
our Lacrosse teams of the past three years.
In order to prove this, let those who do not
play, remember that they can afford assistance
and encouragement to the team by coming to
the games and "rooting."
WWW

HE recent inter-class debate and the standard of excellence attained by the speakers
of both sides, again re-opens the old question,
"Why doesn't Hopkins participate in interuniversity debates ?" Ranking as she does in
point of curriculum and scholastic pre-eminence, our University should certainly be capable of holding her own with any of the "Big
Four" in a debating contest.
Lack of numbers handicaps us to a greater
or less extent upon the athletic field, but in a
case of brain pitted against brain, and muscle,
for the time being, left out of the question, the
odds would not be overwhelmingly against
us. Inter-University debates would bring us
into closer relation with the other great unisities of America, and would enable us to make
comparisons. Finally, as a business proposition, it would possess inestimable advantages
in placing Hopkins more prominently before
the public eye. This would enable the public
not only of Baltimore, but of more remote
places, to pass upon the merits of Hopkins, and
might go far towards enabling us to raise the
necessary funds for our new home.

T

misapprehension has arisen regarding
SOME
an article relating to base ball and last
year's base ball team, which appeared in the
last issue of the NEWS-LETTER. It is certainly
true that lack of interest on the part of the
players themselves was alone responsible for
the discontinuance of the national game at
Hopkins, but while these gentlemen deserve
the censure of the University, the manager of
their team merits no share of the condemnation. His efforts to preserve the morale of the
team and make it a credit to Hopkins were
known to all who were here last year. He
had secured a good schedule and the co-operation of the players was all that was necessary.
Unfortunately this support was not forthcoming, and, despite his efforts, the men would
not work, so consequently the team passed
out of existence.
In justification of Mr. Strouse, we say that
had the other ball-players of last year's nine
been as enthusiastic and faithful as he, base
ball at Hopkins would now be a reality instead
of a sorrowful thing of the past.

The "Eysterian Quartette" did its accustomed stunts and exhausted its stock in trade.
The evening closed with "'Rah for the
Black Boys," and a rousing "Hullabaloo."
The proceeds of the concert are to go towards defraying the expenses incurred by the
Athletic Association in fixing up the new
grounds on the York Road. It is likely that
six or seven hundred dollars will be handed
over to the Athletic Association, and it seems
that every Hopkins man should be grateful to
the Musical Clubs. It should also be known
that the Clubs agreed to give this benefit concert at a time when they were assured of a
large audience at their own concert.

The class of 1900 is arranging with Manager

reunion and dinner, to be held at the Club, on

At its last banquet, the class of '92 decided
to erect a building, or other memorial of the
class, at Homewood, in the event of the University moving there. The committee in charge
of the arrangements consists of Messers.Greenbaum, Stevens, Whitehead, John Stewart, and
Dr. Thos. R. Brown, President of the class.

The University of Glasgow has invited the
Johns Hopkins University to send representatives to its ninth Jubilee, which is to be held
on the 12, 13, and 14 of June. It has been decided to send one delegate from the faculty,
and two from the student body, but final arrangements have not yet been completed. There
will be great pageants and processions, as well
as speeches by prominent men: and the entertainment generally is to be on a grand scale.

Poultney Biglow, who delivered two lectures
on Colonization before the students of historical and political science, March 28 and 30, is a
most interesting character, as scholar, war correspondent, and sportsman. He was the representative of the London "Times" on the
field during the Spanish-American War. He
was the first man to pass in a canoe through
the Iron Gates of the Danube ; and he belongs
to the yacht clubs in Russia, England, and the
United States. His writings on government
and colonial administration, give the view of a
contemporary observer of keen insight, and
are most valuable historical works.

INQUIRY COLUMN.
(In this column the NEWS LETTER will answer, to the best of
its ability, the queries forwarded by correspondents.)

To the Editor:
Could you give me an estimate of the number of students enrolled in the various American colleges?
—Inquirer.
The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER has never
won a prize in a guessing contest, but would
advise Inquirer as a safe way of answering his
question to write to all the colleges for registers. He may then compute the number of
students, and if he will hand his computation
in to us, we will answer his question.

In studying a text book in Physics, I saw the
sentence: "Capacity depends on size," but
my comprehension, limited as all mortals,
could not grasp the meaning of the words.
--Scientist.
Can you explain them?
Not being scientists we scarcely know what
such a sentence means. It can hardly be applied to a person's eating capacity being dependent on his size, for that theory would be
squashed by watching some of our thin i 10
pound Freshmen as they devour sandwiches
and other eatables in the lunch room.

I am very much annoyed at the size and
number of freckles that mar my beauty. I
have tried any number of remedies for them,
but nothing seems to do any good. Perhaps
you can help me.
—A Vassar Freshie.
Here is one cure for the trouble you speak
of that has never been known to fail. We do
not know whether it will help you or not, but
it will not hurt you to try. Just before retiring rub about 5 grains concentrated nitric acid
(H N 03)on the spots affected. If it burns
at first, put some more on. All sense of pain
will soon pass away, and the result will surprise you in the morning.

Please tell me how I should eat the sandwiches sold in the lunch-room. It is rather
hard to manage them without attracting considerable attention to the performance.
—Sub-Fresh.
Proceed as follows: Place sandwich on floor,
and set foot firmly on its neck. Be sure to
use plenty of strength, as you are dealing with
a dangerous creature. Now take your spade
and cut deeply into its back, and before it
can squirm loose, extract the ribs and false
teeth. After this it is harmless. Just break
in small pieces with an ax or sledge, and eat it
before it gets warm. Another thing, don't
mind attracting notice. That's what we're
here for.

T Hopkins when my funds are low,
And cheaply I must live and slow,
How fast and furious is the flow
Of bills that come incessantly.

A

But Hopkins saw another sight,
When aunty up and croaked one night,
For then I'd dough and checks could write;
And creditors came rapidly.
"We're sorry the mistake was made,
We always knew the bills 'd be paid,
And never were the least afraid,"
And thus they spinaged lyingly.
I paid the bills upon the spot,
And from them all receipts I got,
Then proudly turned and viewed the lot
All full of meek apology.
I called them all the names I knew,
Then ope'd the door and pushed them through,
And kicked the last one good and true,
And watched them scatter hurriedly.
I turned around and closed the door,
Then in a heap sank to the floor,
And gave vent to a mighty roar

On the paper before him a figure was drawn
Of circles, and curves, and straight lines,
Rectangles, triangles, points, planes, and so on,
With letters and wonderful signs.
"I've worked here," he said,"for three hours or more,"
And everything now would he well
And as simple and easy as "twice two makes four,"
If these lines were not parallel.
"If they only would meet! How I wish that they
could!"
Then he stopped in amazement and fright—
One parallel line had arisen and bowed,
And the other in tones quite polite,
Was saying, "I'm happy to meet you, in truth,
And it's doubtless quite needless to state
That this pleasure is all unexpected, forsooth,
For men said we never could meet.
But now we are free from such tyrranous laws,"
It was true, as the student could see.
What confusion, what chaos were reigning because
Of the wish he had made recklessly.
He'd noticed two points, well-behaved here-tofore,
Conversing in whispers apart,
They were planning rebellion, of that he was sure;
He listened and heard with faint heart.
"The law that two points on a straight line shall lie,
No longer is binding on us,
I'm not on a straight line with you, so good bye."
0, what a bewildering muss!
Then he saw a point up on a steeple in town,
And a straight line was standing below,
And the wicked point dropped perpendiculars down
In lots of a dozen or so.
"Only one perpendicular, so we are told,
Can be dropped from a point to a line;
Here goes ten or twenty, that law doesn't hold
Any more than the others. How fine!"
Then he saw a triangle, rejoicing because
He possessed two right angles. What fun!
Hitherto, on account of those same irksome laws,
He had never possessed more than one.
A straight line ran up to a circle, and swore
As he stabbed him four times with a knife,
"I could cut you in only two places before,
But this time you forfeit your life."

November 7th, 1900.
While visiting the Paris Exposition of Iwo, the wonderful display of
wines from all parts of the world was made a special study by our representative, who secured some very fine cuvees of French wines, both
red and white, such as Chateau Pontet Canet, Chateau Larose, Chateau Lafitte, Clustcau Margaux, Clarets; Sauternes, Haut Sauternes,
and Chateau Coutet. The latter finer than Chateau Yquem and not so
sweet. Also some special vintag.s of Deinhard & Co.'s celebrated Rhine
Wines selected while visiting their great wine vaults at Coblenz on the
Rhine. The most valuable selection of all was the prize Oporto Port,
the finest of all Wiley Forrester & Co.'s exhibit; a very old, strictly
pure, rich, medicinal Port wine, which will be shipped in 120 gallon
pipes direct from the Exposition ground to
